channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Revolutionize and Democratize the Job Recruitment Game
item.description: An Irvine, California-based software company is looking for developers to help revolutionize and democratize the job recruitment game. If youâ€™re proficient in Perl and enthusiastic about other platforms, such as React or Angular on front-end and Node.js or Python on backend, this could be your opportunity to streamline the job market by helping recruiters make better decisions about candidates.

item.title: Remote Modern Perl, 2-3 month project, $50/hr
item.description: Do you have Modern Perl experience? Not afraid of Plack, DBIx::Class, and writing unit tests? Want to work from home, anywhere in the world, but donâ€™t mind targeting US working hours? We need a few stand-out developers to help a client with a one-off project.

item.title: Sick of jobs lacking purpose? This Perl job literally cures the worldâ€™s ills
item.description: The company is looking for modern Perl developers with a strong interest in Python. You wonâ€™t just be showing off your skills, youâ€™ll be able to expand and build upon them too. Fancy putting your good genes to use in one of Englandâ€™s smartest, most beautiful cities? Want a role that has a tremendously positive impact on society? Get in touch, and letâ€™s get you making a difference.

item.title: Come be a Perl developer in the smartest city in the USA
item.description: We arenâ€™t a sexy Silicon Valley start-up with lots of venture capital backing us and swinging for the fences. Instead, weâ€™re an established business with a long-term reputation for being one of the best hosting companies in the world. We arenâ€™t sexy. Weâ€™re comfortable. And unlike most startups, we know weâ€™ll still be around tomorrow.

item.title: Largest Perl team in London with beautiful Docklands offices
item.description: Large, dynamic Perl team in Canary Wharf looking for mid-level and senior developers. Run by a Perl-loving CTO in beautiful offices with a great view over Canary Wharf, the company manages one legacy Perl codebase and a whole bunch of very new, very shiny, and very modern codebases that power the market-leading solution in their particular area.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland

item.title: European PerlCon 2019
item.description: August 7-9, 2019 Riga, Latvia

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: 2019.28 Perl 6 æ–‡æ¡£ä¹‹ â€“ è¯­è¨€
item.description: Huh, I wonder what the title could be and if that will go through the mailing system intact.

item.title: VigenÃ¨re vs VigenÃ¨re
item.description: Get two and pay for none. The secrets of the VigenÃ¨re Ciphers.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 17: Writing Our Own URL Parser in Perl (But Should We?)
Perl Weekly Challenge 17: The Ackermann function
item.description: Yozen dedicates a blog for each task and I am loving it. You get to learn so much about each task.

item.title: Up, up and Away!
item.description: Veesh use of Mojo::URL for URL parser task looks so simple yet elegant. He also show how bigint can help in the Ackermann function task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 17: Ackermann Function and Parsing URLs
item.description: You must checkout Perl6 solution of Ackermann function task. Even if you don't know Perl6, you can still enjoy it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 17
item.description: Jaldhar blog is ever so informative. You must check out.

item.title: Multitudinal Uniform Resource Parsing â€“ Perl weekly challenge, week 17
item.description: Francis showed how to caching can be used with Perl6 to solve the Ackermann function. Perl6 lover would find the Grammar based solution to URL parser task very informative.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 017: Ackermann Function and URL Parsing
item.description: Choroba introduced Erlang while working on Ackermann function. He always find some new distribution from CPAN to solve the task. This time, he used URI::URL to solve URL parser task. Great learning experience.

item.title: Thoughts on Perl Weekly Challenge 17
item.description: Dave solved the Ackermann function with Memoize. He also show how Mojo::URL can be used to parse URL. Nice writings.

item.title: Ackerman, URL and Perl 6
item.description: Arne used multisubs to solve the Ackermann function. He then used Perl6 Grammar to solve URL parser task. Great blog to read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 017
item.description: Adam literaly converted the task spec into perl subroutine. It can't be any simpler. Great use of Parse::Yapp, I must confess it took me long to get my head around.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 017
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 018
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Super 30 - Anand Kumar
item.description: If you have not read the story of Mohammad S. Anwar, I'd recommend you read that page. Then follow on with what he wrote about Anand Kumar, an Indian educationalist and a mathematician who helps underprivileged students to prepare for the entrance examination for the Indian Institutes of Technology.

item.title: BackupPC 4.3.1 release
item.description: BackupPC is a high-performance, enterprise-grade system for backing up Linux, WinXX, and MacOS PCs and laptops to a server's disk. BackupPC is highly configurable and easy to install and maintain.

item.title: The Time::Local Trap
item.description: Oh I did not know Time::Local uses heuristics (aka. guess) to determine what is the year. Nor that it can handle 2-digit years further perpetuating the Y2K (Year 2000) problem. You always learn something strange.

item.title: Perl Conference in Riga
item.description: No Daner workshop, but two talks by Dave.

item.title: No more false postfix lexical declarations in v5.30
item.description: One less way for Perl programmers to shoot themselves in the leg.

item.title: The Perl Conference in Riga
item.description: Short version: He'll be there. Long version: life was not very easy for Ovid and his family for the past year or so. Details in blog post.

item.title: Using generate_series and daterange for fun and profit
item.description: Showing a calendar for availability of equipment. But how do you handle qequipment that was returned but not yet available for rental? How do you represent damaged equipment?

item.title: Perl jam @Booking.com ML center
item.description: Perl event in Tel Aviv

item.title: Draw customers into your business with incredible window decals from StickerYou.com
item.description: StickerYou can help your small business make a big impact! Ever thought of ordering window decals for your business? Have some already but are growing tired of them? StickerYou.com makes it easy for people to get drawn into your store, restaurant or office with large-format, stunning, die-cut window decals at an unbelievably affordable cost. Use code PERL10 at checkout for a 10% discount exclusive to the Perl community.

item.title: #417 - Perl events after August?
item.description:
Hi there,

There are two Perl events scheduled for August, but no Perl event has been announced beyond that date. At least no event we know about. So are there Perl events in the making that you'd like to publicize?

Enjoy your week
